habitat_description:
Populations of the peninsular leaf-toed gecko are strictly found in southern California and most of Baja California, Mexico. This species occurs in more than 30 islands off the west coast of Baja California (Grismer 2002; Stebbins 2003). The elevation range is from sea level to approximately 610 meters (Stebbins 2003).

The habitat includes riparian zones, bare rock, talus, scree, and desert. This species is associated with rocky areas such as, talus and bedrock. Bedrock habitats, exfoliating slabs, and beach cobble. Plant communities include desert scrub, thornscrub, and chaparral. More specifically, this species is often found under fallen columnar cacti or other decaying vegetation (Grismer 2002; Stebbins 2003). Grismer (2002) reported nocturnal movements into dunes or sandy arroyos, while foraging may take place on tree trunks or the walls of buildings. The eggs are laid among rocks, in crevices, or under exfoliating bark,

Desert scrub, thornscrub, and chaparral. This species is found under fallen columnar cacti and other vegetation.
